subject: p14851532
History: -year-old male with history of non-small cell lung carcinoma status post lung resection adjacent to the major fissure, now presenting with acute chest pain and EKG changes.
Findings: Heterogeneous consolidation within the mid-to-upper left lung corresponds with opacity of concern on prior chest CT, suspicious for reccurrence of malignancy. Additional concerning nodules seen on prior CT are not well characterized on this radiographic examination. Linear opacities in the lung bases and right mid lung likely reflect areas of subsegmental atelectasis. Prominence of the interstitium is likely related to technique. No overt pulmonary edema is evident Blunting of the bilateral costophrenic angles may be due to small bilateral pleural effusions. Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are within normal limits.
Impression: Heterogeneous opacity in the left mid lung, concerning for primary lung malignancy, better characterized on recent prior CT. Possible small bilateral pleural effusions. No overt pulmonary edema.
